188620.title: Remain calm and be prepared to wait.  Showing impatience can increase pressure to pay.  Use any or all of these statements to help you explain why you won't pay.

nodes.text: Remain courteous, respectful and if possible friendly
Make it clear that your company does not allow you to make payments of this kind / that your head office doesn’t allow me to pay any fee that isn’t official
Ask for name and official title of person asking and any identity number
State that you would need an official receipt if you were to pay the fee
Ask to speak to the supervisor/manager of the person making the demand to discuss why you cant pay
Mention that you will contact the embassy / consulate to discuss / report the issue
Explain that you must call your company first to report the issue and to get permission to pay the fee
Take notes or make mental note of the conversations and the time and place for a later report
Report it
Charitable contributions using company funds should usually only be made to charities that have been nominated by the company. Check the company policy or with HR if unsure.
Ask to see evidence of the reason for the donation. Raise this request with your line manager, before proceeding.

As you are in a negotiation process with this person, you should act with caution with a request such as this at this time in case it is a disguised bribe.  People tend to think of bribes as payments of cash or lavish gifts. In fact they are often far less obvious.

Bribery can include approving an irregular payment to win business and is an illegal practice even when done unintentionally. Being asked to sponsor or make a charitable donation can sometimes be a bribe. Engaging in any form of bribery can seriously damage our reputation and our business relationships. Under no circumstances will we ever encourage people even unintentionally to act improperly.

Whilst you may believe that the sponsorship / donation is requested with no ulterior motive it could be misinterpreted by others who could perceive it as a means to make you or your decisions biased, conflicted or obligated.  It is safer to decline than take the risk.
Sponsorship or charitable contributions using company funds should usually only be made to charities that have been nominated by the company.

Do not be embarrassed to ask to see evidence of the reason for the sponsorship / donation or to decline in supporting the charity. Doing so should not change the nature of your business relationship.  Decline in writing being open about the reasons for doing so using the reasons here.
Be transparent.  Report this request to your line manager.

We make no distinction between facilitation payments and bribes, no matter how small the amount. Facilitation payments are illegal in most countries in which we operate and UK law forbids them anywhere in the world.

If you have been offered or have received non promotional gifts from this person or company before, talk to your manager before accepting.

The danger of accepting multiple gifts from suppliers (or other donors) is that, unfairly or not, colleagues and others including other suppliers may question your impartiality and your professional integrity.  The more frequently you accept gifts the more likely this may happen.

Although you may believe that the gifts are offered with no ulterior motive, multiple gifts even of low value, could be misinterpreted by others who could perceive acceptance as making you or your decisions biased, conflicted or obligated.  It maybe safer to decline than to take the risk.

Gifts are a legitimate part of business life and are often exchanged.  However it is possible that accepting a gift can put people into situations which lay them open to accusations of bribery. The more lavish a gift the more likely it is to be regarded with suspicion and its purpose questioned.

We have deliberately limited the type of gift that you can accept in order to protect you from getting into a position where your integrity, impartiality or judgement might be challenged or the company's reputation might be damaged if you accept certain gifts.

The acceptance of this gift would be in breach of the policy and you must not accept it.  Any gifts we do receive in connection with our business should always be customary and reasonable in terms of value and frequency.  As this gift is not within the policy we do not consider it to be reasonable.

Whilst you may believe that the gift is offered with no ulterior motive it could be misinterpreted by others who could perceive the acceptance of the gift as making you or your decisions biased, conflicted or obligated. There can sometimes be a fine line between a gift and a bribe. It is safer to decline than take the risk.

Do not be embarrassed to decline the gift and be clear that you are by doing so in writing.  Simply explain that you are not in a position to accept it using the rules and the reasons given here as explanation.
